title: Myotonic Dystrophy
scope: ** Evaluation and management of myotonic dystrophy type 1 (DM1) and type 2 (DM2) across care settings. Includes diagnostic workup, genetic testing, multisystem assessment (cardiac, respiratory, endocrine, GI, ophthalmologic), symptomatic management of myotonia, and chronic disease monitoring. Covers anesthesia precautions and genetic counseling. Excludes congenital myotonic dystrophy (CDM -- pediatric onset), non-dystrophic myotonias (myotonia congenita, paramyotonia congenita -- see separate plans), and other muscular dystrophies (FSHD, LGMD -- see separate plans).

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Muscle enzyme; typically mildly elevated in DM1 (1-3x ULN) and normal to mildly elevated in DM2; aids in distinguishing from inflammatory myopathies
Essential/Core Labs.target: Normal (30-200 U/L); expect mild elevation (200-600 U/L in DM1; often normal in DM2)

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Renal function baseline; hepatic function; AST/ALT may be mildly elevated from muscle source; glucose assessment given diabetes risk
Essential/Core Labs.target: Normal; mildly elevated AST/ALT may reflect muscle origin

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Baseline blood counts; infection screen if presenting acutely; IgG deficiency and immunologic abnormalities occur in DM1
Insulin resistance and diabetes mellitus are common in DM1 (25-75%); screening essential for multisystem management
Essential/Core Labs.target: Normal (<100 mg/dL); impaired fasting glucose or diabetes common

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Diabetes screening and monitoring; insulin resistance frequent in DM1; less common in DM2
Thyroid dysfunction (hypothyroidism) occurs in myotonic dystrophy; contributes to fatigue and weakness
Complement TSH if abnormal; hypothyroidism common in DM1

Essential/Core Labs.item: Liver function tests (ALT, AST, ALP, bilirubin, albumin) (CPT 80076)
Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Hepatic involvement in DM1; fatty liver and elevated GGT common; baseline before hepatotoxic medications
Essential/Core Labs.target: Normal; mildly elevated GGT and ALT common in DM1

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Hypomagnesemia can exacerbate cardiac conduction abnormalities and myotonia
Hypocalcemia/hypercalcemia can affect myotonia and cardiac conduction
Dyslipidemia screening; metabolic syndrome common in DM1
Baseline renal assessment; screen for myoglobinuria if acute presentation

Extended Workup (Second-line).item: Genetic testing: DMPK gene CTG repeat expansion (DM1) (CPT 81401)
Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: Definitive diagnosis of DM1; CTG trinucleotide repeat expansion on chromosome 19q13.3; normal <37 repeats; DM1 = 50 to >2000 repeats; repeat length correlates with severity and age of onset
Extended Workup (Second-line).target: Normal <37 CTG repeats; mild DM1 50-150; classic DM1 100-1000; congenital DM1 >1000

Extended Workup (Second-line).item: Genetic testing: CNBP (ZNF9) gene CCTG repeat expansion (DM2) (CPT 81401)
Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: Definitive diagnosis of DM2; CCTG tetranucleotide repeat expansion on chromosome 3q21.3; normal <26 repeats; DM2 = 75 to >11,000 repeats; no clear genotype-phenotype correlation
Extended Workup (Second-line).target: Normal <26 CCTG repeats; DM2 typically 75 to >11,000 repeats

Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: Hypogonadism common in DM1 males (60-80%); testicular atrophy; contributes to fatigue, reduced muscle mass, erectile dysfunction
Extended Workup (Second-line).target: Normal male: total 300-1000 ng/dL; expect low or low-normal in DM1

Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: Evaluate hypogonadal axis; primary vs secondary hypogonadism in DM1
Extended Workup (Second-line).target: Normal or elevated FSH/LH (primary hypogonadism pattern in DM1)

Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: Evaluate gonadal function in females with DM1; menstrual irregularities and early menopause
Extended Workup (Second-line).target: Normal for age and menstrual phase

Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: Insulin resistance assessment; hyperinsulinemia precedes overt diabetes in DM1
Extended Workup (Second-line).target: Normal (<25 mIU/L fasting); elevated insulin with normal glucose suggests insulin resistance

Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: Hypogammaglobulinemia (especially IgG) occurs in DM1; increased infection susceptibility
Extended Workup (Second-line).target: Normal IgG (700-1600 mg/dL); low IgG may explain recurrent infections

Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: Elevated in DM1 even without alcohol use; marker of hepatic involvement; distinguish from alcohol-related elevation
Extended Workup (Second-line).target: Normal (<60 U/L); expect mild-moderate elevation in DM1

Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: Deficiency common; worsens weakness and fall risk; important for bone health in patients with limited mobility
Fatigue evaluation; iron deficiency common cause of fatigue superimposed on DM-related fatigue
Extended Workup (Second-line).target: Normal ferritin (30-300 ng/mL); normal iron and TIBC

Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: Coagulation baseline if muscle biopsy needed or pre-procedural

Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.rationale: If DM1 and DM2 testing negative; includes CLCN1 (myotonia congenita), SCN4A (paramyotonia congenita, sodium channel myotonia), KCNJ2 (Andersen-Tawil)
Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.target: Negative for DM1/DM2 mutations; may identify non-dystrophic myotonia

Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.rationale: If inflammatory myopathy in differential; elevated CK with proximal weakness and unclear genetic testing
Late-onset Pompe disease in differential if proximal weakness and respiratory insufficiency without myotonia
Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.target: Normal enzyme activity; reduced suggests Pompe disease

Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.rationale: Cardiac involvement assessment; heart failure screening in symptomatic DM1 patients
Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.target: Normal BNP (<100 pg/mL); elevated suggests cardiac dysfunction

Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.rationale: Acute cardiac injury evaluation if presenting with chest pain or arrhythmia

Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.item: Sleep study referral labs: ABG or SpO2 (CPT 82803)
Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.rationale: Respiratory assessment if hypoventilation or excessive daytime somnolence suspected
Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.target: Normal PaCO2 (35-45 mmHg); SpO2 >95%; elevated PaCO2 suggests hypoventilation

Essential/First-line.timing: At presentation and annually; critical for cardiac conduction abnormality screening (leading cause of sudden death in DM1)
Essential/First-line.target: Normal sinus rhythm; look for first-degree AV block (PR >200ms), bundle branch block, QTc prolongation, atrial flutter/fibrillation; any conduction abnormality requires cardiology referral

Essential/First-line.timing: During initial workup; essential for diagnosis
Essential/First-line.target: Myotonic discharges (waxing-and-waning "dive bomber" sound); myopathic MUAPs (short duration, low amplitude, early recruitment); fibrillations and positive sharp waves; NCS usually normal
Essential/First-line.contraindications: None significant; avoid anticoagulated limbs for needle EMG

Essential/First-line.target: Baseline lung fields; elevated hemidiaphragm suggests diaphragmatic weakness; aspiration pneumonia

Essential/First-line.timing: Within first 3 months of diagnosis; annual thereafter
Essential/First-line.target: Posterior subcapsular cataracts (iridescent "Christmas tree" cataracts pathognomonic for DM1); found in >90% of DM1 and common in DM2

Extended.timing: At diagnosis and annually; more frequently if symptomatic or conduction abnormality on ECG
Extended.target: Normal rhythm; detect intermittent AV block, atrial fibrillation/flutter, ventricular tachycardia, prolonged pauses (>2.5 sec); DM1 patients at risk for sudden cardiac death

Extended.timing: At diagnosis; repeat if symptoms or ECG changes
Extended.target: Normal LV function (EF >55%); assess for LV systolic dysfunction, diastolic dysfunction, mitral valve prolapse (common in DM1); wall motion abnormalities

Extended.timing: At diagnosis and annually; essential for respiratory monitoring
Extended.target: FVC >80% predicted; restrictive pattern (reduced FVC, normal FEV1/FVC ratio); MIP/MEP reduced (respiratory muscle weakness); DLCO usually normal

Extended.item: Maximum inspiratory pressure (MIP) and maximum expiratory pressure (MEP) (CPT 94750)
Extended.timing: At diagnosis and annually; sensitive for respiratory muscle weakness
Extended.target: MIP >60 cm H2O; MEP >40 cm H2O; reduced values indicate diaphragmatic and respiratory muscle weakness requiring intervention

Extended.timing: If excessive daytime somnolence (very common in DM1), snoring, or FVC <70% predicted
Extended.target: No obstructive or central sleep apnea; DM1 patients frequently have OSA, central apnea, and/or sleep-disordered breathing; AHI <5 normal

Extended.timing: If cognitive decline, behavioral changes, or excessive somnolence beyond expected for DM1
Extended.target: White matter hyperintensities (common in DM1); temporal lobe atrophy; cerebral atrophy; assess for extent of CNS involvement
Extended.contraindications: Pacemaker (relative), metallic implants, severe claustrophobia, GFR <30 (gadolinium)

Extended.timing: If dysphagia symptoms present; oropharyngeal weakness common in DM1
Extended.target: Normal swallow mechanics; DM1 may show delayed pharyngeal transit, vallecular residue, aspiration or penetration

Extended.item: MRI thighs (bilateral, with and without contrast) (CPT 73721)
Extended.timing: For disease monitoring or if diagnosis uncertain; assess muscle involvement pattern
Extended.target: DM1: preferential fatty infiltration of medial gastrocnemius, soleus, tibialis anterior (distal > proximal); DM2: preferential involvement of hip flexors, hip extensors, quadriceps (proximal > distal)
Extended.contraindications: Pacemaker, metallic implants, severe claustrophobia, GFR <30 (gadolinium)

Rare/Specialized.timing: If echocardiogram abnormal or high clinical suspicion for myocardial fibrosis; risk stratification for sudden cardiac death
Rare/Specialized.target: Normal myocardium; late gadolinium enhancement indicates fibrosis/scarring (predictor of arrhythmia risk); assess LV function
Rare/Specialized.contraindications: Pacemaker (relative -- MRI-conditional devices acceptable), metallic implants, GFR <30 (gadolinium)

Rare/Specialized.timing: If syncope, near-syncope, or significant conduction abnormalities; risk stratification for sudden cardiac death
Rare/Specialized.target: Normal conduction intervals; prolonged HV interval (>70ms) predicts high-degree AV block risk and may warrant pacemaker/ICD

Rare/Specialized.timing: Only if genetic testing inconclusive and diagnosis uncertain; rarely needed given availability of genetic testing
Rare/Specialized.target: DM1: increased central nuclei, type 1 fiber atrophy, ring fibers, sarcoplasmic masses, pyknotic nuclear clumps; DM2: type 2 fiber atrophy (distinguishing feature), nuclear clumps

Rare/Specialized.timing: If cognitive concerns or behavioral changes; DM1 frequently involves CNS (executive dysfunction, apathy, visuospatial deficits)
Rare/Specialized.target: Normal for age; DM1 patients often show executive dysfunction, reduced processing speed, apathy, attention deficits, reduced motivation; DM2 milder cognitive involvement

Rare/Specialized.timing: If gastroparesis symptoms (nausea, bloating, early satiety, vomiting); GI dysmotility common in DM1
Rare/Specialized.target: Normal gastric emptying (>90% at 4 hours); delayed emptying indicates gastroparesis

dosing.instructions: Start 150 mg PO BID; increase to 150 mg TID after 1-2 weeks; may increase to 200 mg TID; max 900 mg/day; take with food to reduce GI side effects

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Insulin resistance and type 2 diabetes mellitus in DM1; first-line oral hypoglycemic

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Hypothyroidism treatment in DM1 patients with confirmed thyroid dysfunction

dosing.instructions: Start 25-50 mcg PO daily (lower dose in elderly or cardiac disease); titrate by 12.5-25 mcg q6-8 weeks based on TSH; take on empty stomach 30-60 min before breakfast

dosing.instructions: Start 300 mg PO qHS; increase by 300 mg/day every 3-5 days; target 900-1800 mg/day divided TID; max 3600 mg/day; reduce dose if CrCl <60

Referrals & Consults.item: Neuromuscular specialist for diagnostic confirmation, genetic testing coordination, multisystem disease management, and longitudinal monitoring of DM1/DM2
Cardiology for cardiac conduction abnormality assessment, annual ECG/Holter monitoring, pacemaker/ICD evaluation, and arrhythmia management (leading cause of sudden death in DM1)
Pulmonology for respiratory function monitoring, sleep-disordered breathing evaluation, non-invasive ventilation titration, and management of respiratory muscle weakness
Ophthalmology for annual slit-lamp examination to monitor posterior subcapsular cataracts (>90% prevalence in DM1) and surgical planning when visually significant
Endocrinology for diabetes mellitus management, thyroid dysfunction treatment, hypogonadism evaluation and testosterone replacement, and metabolic syndrome optimization

Genetic counseling for autosomal dominant inheritance education, anticipation phenomenon explanation (earlier onset and increased severity in successive generations), family member testing, and reproductive planning
Speech-language pathology for swallow evaluation given oropharyngeal weakness and dysarthria risk in DM1; aspiration prevention strategies
Physical therapy for individualized exercise program (low-to-moderate intensity), gait training, fall prevention, and assistive device fitting given progressive weakness
Occupational therapy for ADL adaptation, hand function optimization (grip myotonia management), energy conservation, and home modification assessment

Anesthesiology pre-operative consultation REQUIRED before any surgical procedure; DM patients at high risk for malignant hyperthermia-like reactions, cardiac arrhythmias, prolonged recovery, respiratory failure; succinylcholine is CONTRAINDICATED
Gastroenterology for GI dysmotility evaluation, gastroparesis management, pseudo-obstruction assessment, and gallbladder disease screening (cholelithiasis common in DM1)

Psychiatry/Psychology for cognitive-behavioral assessment, depression/anxiety treatment, apathy management, and neuropsychological testing in DM1 (CNS involvement causes executive dysfunction and personality changes)
Social work for disability evaluation assistance, insurance navigation, community resources, vocational rehabilitation, and caregiver support
Physiatry (PM&R) for comprehensive rehabilitation planning, durable medical equipment prescription, orthotic fitting (AFOs for foot drop), and disability evaluation
Sleep medicine for excessive daytime somnolence evaluation, polysomnography interpretation, CPAP/BiPAP titration, and central hypersomnia management
Palliative care for goals of care discussion, symptom management optimization, advance care planning, and quality of life support in advanced disease

Patient Instructions.item: Return to ED immediately if palpitations, lightheadedness, syncope, or near-syncope (may indicate cardiac arrhythmia or heart block -- leading cause of sudden death in DM1)
Return to ED if new difficulty breathing, worsening shortness of breath, or morning headaches (may indicate respiratory muscle weakness or hypoventilation requiring ventilatory support)
Return to ED if fall with head injury, inability to get up, or new severe pain (progressive weakness increases fall risk)
Return to ED if choking during eating or drinking, inability to swallow medications, or recurrent coughing with meals (aspiration risk from oropharyngeal weakness)
Return to ED if fever with cough or difficulty breathing (may indicate aspiration pneumonia given dysphagia risk)

CRITICAL: Inform ALL healthcare providers and anesthesiologists of myotonic dystrophy diagnosis before ANY surgical or dental procedure; succinylcholine is CONTRAINDICATED; risk of malignant hyperthermia-like reaction, cardiac arrhythmia, and prolonged recovery from anesthesia
Carry a medical alert bracelet or card identifying myotonic dystrophy diagnosis and "No Succinylcholine" warning for emergency situations
Use assistive devices as recommended by PT/OT (AFOs for foot drop, cane, walker) to prevent falls; early adoption improves safety
Expect slow but progressive weakness over years; DM is a chronic condition without cure, but proactive multisystem monitoring significantly improves quality of life and prevents complications
Attend annual cardiac monitoring (ECG and Holter) even if asymptomatic; conduction abnormalities can develop without symptoms and cause sudden cardiac death
Report new or worsening daytime sleepiness, snoring, or morning headaches to neurology (may indicate sleep apnea or hypoventilation requiring CPAP/BiPAP)
Do not drive if excessive daytime somnolence or cardiac arrhythmia is present; discuss driving safety with neurology
Inform family members that myotonic dystrophy is inherited (autosomal dominant); children have a 50% chance of inheriting the condition; genetic counseling available for family planning
Be aware of anticipation: children (especially those inheriting from mother) may develop more severe, earlier-onset disease; genetic counseling and prenatal testing are available

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Low-to-moderate intensity exercise program (walking, swimming, stationary cycling) 3-5 days per week to maintain cardiovascular fitness and slow deconditioning; avoid extreme exertion which may worsen weakness
High-protein diet (1.0-1.5 g/kg/day protein) to support muscle preservation; adequate caloric intake to prevent weight loss from dysphagia or GI dysmotility
Home safety evaluation by OT to remove fall hazards, install grab bars, raised toilet seat, shower bench, stair rails, and adequate lighting given progressive weakness and fall risk
Annual influenza vaccination (inactivated) and pneumococcal vaccination per guidelines given respiratory muscle weakness and aspiration risk
Strict glycemic control (HbA1c <7%) to prevent diabetic complications and neuropathy progression in DM patients with insulin resistance or diabetes
Alcohol limitation as alcohol worsens respiratory depression, increases fall risk, exacerbates hepatic dysfunction, and interacts with CNS-depressant medications
Smoking cessation to reduce respiratory infection risk and improve pulmonary function (already compromised by respiratory muscle weakness)
CPAP/BiPAP compliance essential for patients with sleep-disordered breathing to prevent nocturnal hypoxia, morning headaches, and daytime somnolence
Adequate sleep hygiene (consistent schedule, 7-9 hours) to manage DM1-related hypersomnia; avoid sedating medications when possible
Weight management to reduce metabolic burden and improve mobility; obesity worsens insulin resistance and respiratory function in DM
Vitamin D supplementation to maintain level >30 ng/mL for muscle and bone health; higher dose repletion if deficient
Fall prevention program including balance exercises, home modifications, medication review for fall-risk-increasing medications, and vision correction (cataracts)
Advance care planning discussion including code status, ventilatory support preferences, and goals of care early in disease course while patient can fully participate in decision-making

differential.features: Non-dystrophic myotonia; pure myotonia WITHOUT progressive weakness or systemic features; onset in childhood; muscle hypertrophy rather than atrophy; no cardiac involvement; no cataracts; CLCN1 gene mutation
differential.tests: Genetic testing (CLCN1 mutation; negative DMPK/CNBP); EMG (myotonic discharges but no myopathic MUAPs); no systemic features; normal cardiac evaluation

differential.features: Cold-induced myotonia (paradoxical -- worsens with repeated activity unlike classic myotonia); episodic weakness; SCN4A gene mutation; no progressive weakness or systemic involvement
differential.tests: Genetic testing (SCN4A mutation); cold provocation test; EMG with cooling; no systemic features; no cataracts; normal cardiac evaluation

differential.features: Symmetric proximal weakness; subacute onset; higher CK (10-50x ULN); NO myotonia; responsive to immunotherapy; no cataracts; no cardiac conduction disease; no genetic basis
differential.tests: CK (much higher); EMG (irritable myopathy WITHOUT myotonic discharges); muscle biopsy (endomysial CD8+ invasion without rimmed vacuoles); myositis-specific antibodies; steroid response

differential.features: Onset >50 years; finger flexor and quadriceps weakness pattern; NO myotonia; poor response to immunotherapy; rimmed vacuoles on biopsy; anti-cN1A antibody
differential.tests: EMG (mixed myopathic/neurogenic WITHOUT myotonic discharges); anti-cN1A antibody; muscle biopsy (rimmed vacuoles, amyloid deposits); no genetic trinucleotide repeat expansion

differential.features: Progressive proximal weakness; NO myotonia; variable CK elevation; no systemic features (no cataracts, no cardiac conduction disease, no diabetes); specific genetic subtypes
differential.tests: Genetic testing panel (>30 subtypes); no myotonic discharges on EMG; no trinucleotide repeat expansion; muscle biopsy (dystrophic changes, specific protein deficiencies)

differential.features: Upper AND lower motor neuron signs; fasciculations; NO myotonia; no systemic features; rapid progression; bulbar onset with dysarthria common
differential.tests: EMG (widespread denervation, fasciculations, NO myotonic discharges); no cardiac or endocrine involvement; no cataracts; no genetic trinucleotide repeat

differential.features: Proximal weakness; fatigue; delayed relaxation of reflexes (may mimic myotonia clinically); elevated CK; reversible with thyroid replacement; no true electrical myotonia on EMG
differential.tests: TSH (elevated); free T4 (low); EMG (no myotonic discharges -- delayed relaxation is not electrical myotonia); CK normalizes with treatment; no genetic testing needed

differential.features: Temporal correlation with drug exposure; myalgia and weakness; may have myotonic features on EMG; improves with drug discontinuation; no systemic features
differential.tests: Medication history; improvement after drug withdrawal; negative genetic testing for DM1/DM2; no cataracts or cardiac conduction disease

differential.features: Childhood onset; continuous muscle stiffness (not true myotonia); short stature; blepharospasm; skeletal abnormalities; HSPG2 gene mutation
differential.tests: Genetic testing (HSPG2); childhood onset; skeletal features; EMG (high-frequency discharges but not classic myotonic discharges); no systemic features of DM

differential.features: Exercise-induced muscle stiffness (silent contractures -- no electrical activity on EMG); ATP2A1 gene mutation; no percussion myotonia; no systemic features
differential.tests: EMG (electrically silent contractures -- NO myotonic discharges); genetic testing (ATP2A1); no cataracts; no cardiac conduction disease

differential.features: Proximal weakness; respiratory muscle weakness disproportionate to limb weakness; mildly elevated CK; NO myotonia; autosomal recessive
differential.tests: Acid alpha-glucosidase activity (reduced); GAA gene testing; EMG (myopathic without myotonic discharges in most -- some rare cases show myotonic discharges); no cardiac conduction disease

evidence.recommendation: Myotonic dystrophy clinical practice guidelines (comprehensive)
DM1 genetics: CTG trinucleotide repeat expansion on DMPK gene (chromosome 19)
DM2 genetics: CCTG tetranucleotide repeat expansion on CNBP/ZNF9 gene (chromosome 3)
Anticipation in DM1: progressive expansion of CTG repeats across generations with earlier onset and greater severity
Cardiac conduction abnormalities as leading cause of mortality in DM1

Prophylactic pacemaker implantation in DM1 with conduction abnormalities

Modafinil for excessive daytime somnolence in DM1
Respiratory involvement in myotonic dystrophy: diaphragmatic weakness, restrictive pattern, sleep-disordered breathing
Sleep-disordered breathing and central hypersomnia in DM1
Insulin resistance and diabetes in DM1

monitoring.frequency: Annually minimum; more frequently if conduction abnormalities present; at any new cardiac symptom
monitoring.action: If new conduction abnormality: urgent cardiology referral; Holter monitor; consider EPS; pacemaker/ICD evaluation; PR >240ms or HV >70ms warrants device consideration

monitoring.frequency: Annually in DM1; q2-3 years in DM2 if asymptomatic; more frequently if abnormal
monitoring.action: If significant arrhythmia: electrophysiology study; pacemaker/ICD evaluation; antiarrhythmic consideration (but most are contraindicated in DM1)

monitoring.frequency: Annually; q6 months if FVC <70% predicted or symptoms
monitoring.action: If FVC declining or <60%: pulmonology referral; sleep study; BiPAP initiation; discuss advance care planning if FVC <40%
If cataracts progressing and visually significant: ophthalmology surgical planning with anesthesia precautions; correct refractive error

monitoring.frequency: Annually if normal; q3-6 months if diabetic or prediabetic
monitoring.action: If prediabetes: lifestyle modification, metformin consideration; if diabetes: initiate or optimize treatment; endocrinology referral
If elevated: confirm with free T4; initiate levothyroxine; recheck q6-8 weeks; endocrinology referral if complex

monitoring.frequency: Annually in symptomatic males; at diagnosis
monitoring.action: If low with symptoms: endocrinology referral; testosterone replacement; monitor PSA and hematocrit

monitoring.frequency: Annually; q6 months if on hepatotoxic medications
monitoring.action: If progressive elevation: hepatology referral; abdominal ultrasound; reassess medications; fatty liver common in DM1

monitoring.frequency: Every clinic visit; q6-12 months formal assessment
monitoring.action: If accelerated decline: reassess for superimposed conditions; optimize rehabilitation; adjust assistive devices

monitoring.frequency: Each clinic visit clinical screening; MBSS if symptomatic
monitoring.action: If worsening dysphagia: SLP re-evaluation; diet modification; MBSS; aspiration precautions; consider PEG if severe

monitoring.frequency: Annually minimum; more frequently if concerns
monitoring.action: If PHQ-9 >=10: assess safety; initiate antidepressant; psychology/psychiatry referral

monitoring.frequency: Annually; more frequently if EDS or OSA present
monitoring.action: If ESS >=10: sleep study; CPAP/BiPAP evaluation; modafinil consideration; sleep hygiene review

monitoring.frequency: Baseline; q2 years; sooner if fracture or steroid exposure
monitoring.action: If T-score <-2.5: bisphosphonate; calcium/vitamin D optimization; endocrine referral; fall prevention critical
If weight loss >5% in 6 months: reassess dysphagia; nutrition consultation; calorie supplementation; GI evaluation

disposition.criteria: Ambulatory (with or without assistive device); safe swallow; adequate oral intake; cardiac rhythm stable (no new conduction abnormality requiring monitoring); pain controlled; respiratory status stable; outpatient neuromuscular and cardiology follow-up arranged; home safety adequate; understands return precautions and anesthesia warnings

Fall-related injury requiring monitoring (fracture, head injury); aspiration pneumonia requiring IV antibiotics; new cardiac conduction abnormality requiring telemetry monitoring; new diagnosis requiring expedited inpatient workup; severe dehydration or malnutrition from dysphagia; respiratory decompensation not requiring ICU; pre-operative optimization for urgent surgery

Respiratory failure from aspiration pneumonia or respiratory muscle weakness requiring mechanical ventilation or non-invasive ventilation; hemodynamically significant arrhythmia (complete heart block, sustained VT); post-anesthesia prolonged respiratory depression or malignant hyperthermia-like reaction; cardiac arrest from conduction disease

disposition.disposition: Transfer to higher level of care
disposition.criteria: Need for neuromuscular specialist not available locally; electrophysiology study and pacemaker/ICD implantation not available on-site; cardiac MRI not available; genetic counseling services unavailable
Significant functional decline with deconditioning; post-fall with functional decline; able to participate in 3 hours/day therapy; medically stable; benefit expected from intensive PT/OT
